Let $f(n)$ count the number of solutions to $k\sigma(k)=n$, where $\sigma(k)$ is the sum of divisors of $k$. Is it true that $f(n)\leq n^{o(\frac{1}{\log\log n})}$? Perhaps even $\leq (\log n)^{O(1)}$?



This is discussed in problem B11 of Guy's collection \cite{Gu04}.




References


[Gu04] Guy, Richard K., Unsolved problems in number theory. (2004), xviii+437.


Back to the problem

knowledge.progressSummary: PARTIAL (OPEN): Erdos1060Problem.lean (241 lines, 2 axioms, 6 sorries). Counting solutions to k·σ(k)=n. Core infrastructure built. Two main conjectures axiomatized: weak (n^o(1/log log n)) and strong ((log n)^O(1)).
builtItems: Example computations: g(2)=6, g(3)=12, g(6)=72, etc.
insights: Status: OPEN (both weak and strong conjectures)
f(n) counts solutions to k·σ(k) = n
Solution set finite: k·σ(k) ≥ k implies k ≤ n
Weak bound: f(n) ≤ n^{ε/log log n} for large n
Strong bound: f(n) ≤ (log n)^C (polynomial in log)

Let $f(n)$ count the number of solutions to $k\sigma(k)=n$, where $\sigma(k)$ is the sum of divisors of $k$. Is it true that $f(n)\leq n^{o(\frac{1}{\log\log n})}$? Perhaps even $\leq (\log n)^{O(1)}$?



This is discussed in problem B11 of Guy's collection \cite{Gu04}.
